meta.persona_tagline: Helping my child navigate anxiety that mirrors my own childhood.

developmental_story.childhood_environment: Sarah grew up in a seemingly stable, middle-class home in suburban St. Louis. However, beneath the surface, her mother struggled with undiagnosed anxiety and a tendency towards over-control. Sarah's father worked long hours and was emotionally distant, leaving Sarah to navigate her own anxieties largely alone. She learned early on to suppress her feelings to avoid upsetting her mother.
developmental_story.adolescence: Sarah's anxiety intensified during adolescence. The pressure to perform well in school, fit in socially, and navigate the complexities of teenage relationships became overwhelming. She developed perfectionistic tendencies and struggled with social anxiety, often isolating herself from her peers. She briefly saw a therapist for anxiety in 8th grade, but stopped going when she felt better.
developmental_story.early_adulthood: Sarah excelled academically and went on to earn a bachelor's degree in accounting. She met her husband in college and they married shortly after graduation. She worked full-time as an accountant, but found the demanding work environment and long hours triggering for her anxiety. She switched to part-time work after her son, Owen, was born.
developmental_story.family_structure: Sarah was raised by both parents in a two-parent household. She has one younger brother who is successful and lives out of state. Her parents are still married, though their relationship has always been somewhat strained by her mother's anxiety.
developmental_story.educational_journey: Sarah was a high-achieving student throughout her educational journey. She attended private schools and excelled academically. She went to a local university and graduated with honors.
pivotal_moments: Starting therapy in 8th grade for a short time
Becoming a mother and feeling overwhelmed by the responsibility
Recognizing anxiety symptoms in her son
Deciding to seek therapy for her son
developmental_story.intergenerational_patterns: Sarah's mother struggled with anxiety, and Sarah now sees similar patterns emerging in her son. She is determined to break this cycle and provide her son with the support and resources she lacked as a child.

neurodivergence_mental_health.diagnosis_journey: Sarah has not been formally diagnosed with anxiety, but recognizes that she has struggled with anxiety symptoms since childhood. She is considering seeking a formal diagnosis for herself after recognizing similar symptoms in her son.
neurodivergence_mental_health.how_it_shows_up: Sarah experiences racing thoughts, difficulty sleeping, and physical symptoms such as stomachaches and headaches. She tends to overthink situations and anticipate worst-case scenarios. She finds it difficult to relax and often feels on edge.
neurodivergence_mental_health.nervous_system_pattern: High strung, reactive, prone to overwhelm. Seeks control as a means to manage anxiety.

ef_friction_points: Trouble with emotional regulation when anxious
ef_workarounds: Using a planner to stay organized
Breaking down tasks into smaller steps
Setting timers to stay on track
executive_function_sensory.sensory_profile: Sensitive to loud noises and bright lights. Prefers calm and quiet environments. Can become easily overwhelmed by sensory overload.
executive_function_sensory.food_sensory_details: Prefers bland, predictable foods. Avoids anything with a strong odor or unusual texture. Safe foods include: plain pasta with butter, grilled chicken breast, apple slices, and Cheerios. Dislikes foods with visible fat or gristle. Only eats chicken if it's grilled and room temperature. Texture is a big issue; anything slimy or mushy is a no-go. Doesn't eat enough when stressed.

current_life_context.where_they_live: Comfortable two-story house in a quiet, family-friendly neighborhood in Kirkwood, MO.
current_life_context.work_school_situation: Works part-time as an accountant. Her son, Owen, is in elementary school.
current_life_context.commute_daily_rhythms: Drives her son to and from school each day. Works from home a few days a week and commutes to the office on other days. Spends evenings helping her son with homework and preparing dinner.
current_life_context.support_system: Her husband, a few close friends, and her parents.

goals_barriers.why_therapy_now: My son has expressed to me that he wants to talk to a therapist because he's having a lot of anxiety lately, especially when storms are developing.
what_they_want_to_change: Help her son develop coping skills
whats_in_the_way: Her own anxiety about seeking help
Finding the right therapist for her son

narrative_voice.quote_struggle: He has expressed to me that he wants to talk to a therapist.
quotes_additional: Do you have any availability in the after school hours?
narrative_voice.liz_clinical_narrative: Sarah's story is one of quiet strength and a deep desire to protect her son from the anxieties she herself has carried for so long. She recognizes the intergenerational patterns at play and is bravely seeking support not only for Owen, but potentially for herself as well. Her initial hesitation is understandable given her own experiences and the lingering stigma surrounding mental health. Our goal would be to create a safe and supportive space for both Sarah and Owen to explore their anxieties, develop coping strategies, and build resilience. We'll focus on gentle, evidence-based approaches tailored to their individual needs, empowering them to navigate life's challenges with greater confidence and peace.
narrative_voice.therapy_preferences: After-school appointments, therapist experienced with childhood anxiety, preferably accepts BCBS insurance but willing to pay privately.

website_copy_snippets: Is your child struggling with anxiety? We provide neurodivergent-affirming therapy to help children and families thrive.
Recognizing anxiety in your child can be overwhelming. We offer compassionate support and evidence-based treatments to help your child develop coping skills and build resilience.
Anxiety running in your family? Break the cycle with our specialized therapy services.
content_angles: How to recognize anxiety in your child
Tips for helping your child cope with anxiety
Choosing the right therapist for your child
Breaking the cycle of intergenerational anxiety
